metadata.description: Data imputation, binning, encoding, and more! Learn all the steps with mastery!

all_paragraphs: Feature transformation is the process of modifying your data but keeping the information. These modifications will make Machine Learning algorithms understanding easier, which will deliver better results.
We’ll cover all the steps for each method, from explanation to code; But first, let’s take a look at what we will learn today:
You can download the dataset by clicking here. Now, we need to define some parameters and questions to answer.

This artificial data set simulate some data about the possibility of heart disease, which is our goal. To find out, we have some false medical information, like blood pressure, age, and sodium amount.
The first thing you want to do when obtaining new data is to check it and look for missing values; Let’s see how it looks.

I added some empty values ​​at random to this dataset, ignoring the heart disease column. As for our method, it is okay to use Pandas functions for small data sets; But if you have bigger ones, consider using scikit-learn.
In Pandas, we have a nice function called fillna() that, as you can imagine, will fill any empty value. Let’s take a look.
Simple, right? It will produce the changes below.
How simple it was! One line of code and that’s it, awesome! But calm down, there is a problem: we define the same value as categorical and numerical, this is not right, so what to do?
Now, we have the average value of the entire column filling empty spaces in numerical resources and the “missing” text in categorical spaces.

Before proceeding, we need to look for discrepancies in our numerical columns, as they can affect the quality of our model. Based on a specific problem, it is best to keep each value, but you need to know how to remove them anyway.

You can usually use some graphical tools to display them, such as Matplotlib. The type of chart? Histogram and boxplot, usually. Don’t know how to plot your data? I have an article about it: The ultimate guide for Data Visualization.
We will check our data representation without outliers below.
For the sake of knowledge, I have attached a single case that changes a person’s age to 134, a rarity.
You may not be comfortable with the visualizations or just want something more to the point. If you fit the description above, I’ll leave the code to create a DataFrame with only outliers.
With a lot of outliers, our model will create patterns that use these values, but they are usually just typos, false data, and so on.
There are usually two common ways to remove outliers: standard deviation and interquartile range. There are more like the Z-score and even manual removal, but let’s ignore them for now.

Using the standard deviation, we can select only those data that are between +3 or -3 standard deviations from the mean. This value can be adjusted, but it usually ranges from 2 to 4. If you are unsure how to use standard deviations, click here to watch a Khan Academy video.
To remove outliers in this way, we need to obtain the first and third quartiles. The data must be in ascending order.

It is much easier to code our data set with any tool in the scikit-learn library, but this is a Pandas manual, so we will do this manually.
The computer reads numbers, even the most complex ones. It is much easier to understand numerical data rather than categorical, which is why we do this.

As you can see, we are beginning to receive important information from our data:

Machines don’t understand scale as we do. You can easily find the difference between your salary and your weight, knowing that it is impossible to weigh as much as you receive monthly, but the computer does not; That’s why we scale the entire data set. In a basic way, there are two ways to scale: Standardization and Normalization.

Also known as Z-score Normalization, this method resizes our data to have a median of zero and a standard deviation of 1. In the end, no matter how different their values ​​are, they will have the same representation.
It is extremely useful, reducing the effects of overfitting resources, so use it.
Also known as min-max normalization, this method resizes our data to a fixed value between 0 and 1.

As it is not a project that focuses on each step of the Machine Learning model workflow, I will leave the basic score of three randomly obtained algorithms. This is a classification problem, don’t forget. Our evaluation method will be an accuracy score and a confusion matrix.

Unfortunately, we don’t have enough data to improve our model, and our first model (RandomForest) may be overfitted. Don’t forget this: the more data you have, the more capable your algorithm will be. Let’s check the confusion matrix.

Look at this! RandomForest was excellent! But pay attention now: the last two have false positives and negatives. Our last two models sometimes predicted it wrong. This is not good, in fact. It can certainly be improved.
